tit.e: The Local Bureaucratic System of Ancient Japan
The Local Bureaucratic System of Ancient Japan
The Local Bureaucratic System of Ancient Japan

sen.j: 地方官制（ちほうかんせい）は、701年（大宝元）に制定された大宝律令で国・郡・里の三段階の行政組織に編成された。
sen.e: The Local Bureaucratic System was formed into a three-tier administrative organization of kuni (provinces), gun/kori (districts) and ri/sato (villages) under the Taiho Code enacted in the year 701.
The Local Bureaucratic System was formed into a three-tier administrative organization of kuni (provinces), gun/kori (districts) and ri/sato (villages) under the Taiho Code enacted in the year 701.

The local bureaucratic system was formed into a three-tier administrative organization of kuni (provinces), gun/kori (districts) and ri/sato (villages) under the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) enacted in the year 701.
sen.cmt: 大宝律令 を追加しました。

tit.e: The Beginning of the Local Bureaucratic System
The Beginning of the Local Bureaucratic System
The beginning of the local bureaucratic system
tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 4世紀～6世紀頃？
sen.e: 4th century - 6th century?
4th century - 6th century?
ca. fourth century - sixth century

sen.j: 『古事記』成務段
sen.e: "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), Seimu Section
"Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), Seimu Section
"Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), Seimu Section

sen.j: 「大国小国の国造（くにのみやつこ）を定めたまい、また国々の堺、及び大県（おおあがた）小県（おあがた）の県主（あがたぬし）を定めたまう。」
sen.e: Kuni no miyatsuko (the heads of local governments) for large and small provinces were not appointed, nor were provincial borders fixed or agatanushi (territorial rulers) of large and small territories installed.

Kuni no miyatsuko (the heads of local governments) for large and small provinces were not appointed, nor were provincial borders fixed or agatanushi (territorial rulers) of large and small territories installed.

Kuni no miyatsuko (the heads of local governments) for large and small provinces were appointed, provincial borders were fixed, and agatanushi (territorial rulers) of large and small territories were installed.
sen.cmt: 「くにのみやつこ」、及び「あがたぬし」は「定められた」と解釈し、左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』成務紀
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Seimu Records
"Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Seimu Records
"Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Seimu Records

sen.j: 4年「今より以降国郡に長を立て、県邑に首を置かむ。即ち当国の幹了しき者を取りて、其の国郡の首長に任ぜよ。」
sen.e: Year 4 "Appoint heads of provinces and districts, install chiefs of territories and villages.
Year 4 "Appoint heads of provinces and districts, install chiefs of territories and villages.
Year 4 'Appoint heads of provinces and districts, install chiefs of territories and villages; appoint the ruler of this province as head of that province and district.'

sen.j: 5年「国郡に造長を立て、県邑に稲置を置く。」
sen.e: Year 5 "Appoint a head of officials and install inagi (regional administrators during the Yamato Dynasty)."
Year 5 "Appoint a head of officials and install inagi (regional administrators during the Yamato Dynasty)."
Year 5 'Appoint a head of officials and install inagi (regional administrators during the Yamato Dynasty).'

sen.j: 「則ち山河を隔（さか）いて国郡を分ち、阡陌に随ひて、邑里を定む。」
sen.e: "Separate provinces and districts according to mountains and rivers, and establish villages according to road senpaku."
"Separate provinces and districts according to mountains and rivers, and establish villages according to road senpaku."
'Separate provinces and districts according to mountains and rivers, and establish villages according to road senpaku.'

sen.j: （阡陌は南北・東西の道の意）
sen.e: "Senpaku" refers to roads that run north-south and east-west".
"Senpaku" refers to roads that run north-south and east-west".
("Senpaku" refers to roads that run north-south and east-west.)

sen.j: 成務天皇は13代で、応神天皇（15代）仁徳天皇（16代）や倭の五王よりも遡る4世紀のことで、時代でいうと古墳時代の前期にあたる。
sen.e: Emperor Seimu was the 13th emperor of Japan and lived in the 4th century before Emperor Ojin (15th), Emperor Nintoku (16th) and the five kings of Wa in what was the first half of the Kofun period.
Emperor Seimu was the 13th emperor of Japan and lived in the 4th century before Emperor Ojin (15th), Emperor Nintoku (16th) and the five kings of Wa in what was the first half of the Kofun period.

Emperor Seimu was the 13th emperor of Japan and lived in the 4th century before Emperor Ojin (15th), Emperor Nintoku (16th) and the five kings of Wa (Japan) in what was the first half of the Kofun period.
sen.cmt: 倭→Wa (Japan) と補足しました。

sen.j: この時代に全国的に国造・県主を配置したとは考えがたく、記事そのものは『日本書紀』の潤色であると考えられている。
sen.e: It is difficult to contemplate that kuni no miyatsuko and agatanushi were stationed throughout the entire country, and these references are thought to be rhetorical flourishes of "Nihonshoki".
It is difficult to contemplate that kuni no miyatsuko and agatanushi were stationed throughout the entire country, and these references are thought to be rhetorical flourishes of "Nihonshoki".

It is difficult to contemplate that kuni no miyatsuko and agatanushi were stationed throughout the entire country during this peirod, and these references are thought to be rhetorical flourishes of "Nihonshoki."
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を移動しました。

sen.j: また成務天皇自体の実在性が疑われている。
sen.e: Moreover, the actual exisitance of Emperor Seimu is in doubt.
Moreover, the actual exisitance of Emperor Seimu is in doubt.
Moreover, the actual existence of Emperor Seimu is in doubt.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、この記事が、ヤマト王権において、服属させた周辺の豪族を県主として把握し、県主によって支配される領域を県（アガタ）と呼んでいたことを伝えていると考えることはできる。
sen.e: However, it can be though that these articles refer to the fact that, during the Yamato Dynasty, powerful families of areas loyal to the court were controlled by being appointed agatanushi and that the areas ruled by agatanushi were called agata.

However, it can be though that these articles refer to the fact that, during the Yamato Dynasty, powerful families of areas loyal to the court were controlled by being appointed agatanushi and that the areas ruled by agatanushi were called agata.

However, it can be thought that these articles refer to the fact that, during the Yamato Dynasty, powerful families of areas loyal to the court were controlled by being appointed agatanushi and that the areas ruled by agatanushi were called agata.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 6世紀後半～7世紀中？
sen.e: Latter part of the 6th century - middle of the 7th century?
Latter part of the 6th century - middle of the 7th century?
ca. latter part of the sixth century - middle of the seventh century

sen.j: 『日本書紀』安閑天皇二年（535）5月に屯倉の大量設置の記事がみられるが、これらの屯倉の名前の多くが、現存する地名と一致し、その実在を確認できる。
sen.e: "Nihon Shoki" contains articles relating to the establishment of numerous miyake (imperially controlled territories) in May 535 but the names of many of these miyake match surviving place names and their existence can be confirmed.

"Nihon Shoki" contains articles relating to the establishment of numerous miyake (imperially controlled territories) in May 535 but the names of many of these miyake match surviving place names and their existence can be confirmed.

"Nihon Shoki" contains articles relating to the establishment of numerous miyake (imperially controlled territories) in June 535 but the names of many of these miyake match surviving place names and their existence can be confirmed.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: また、同年八月の条に、犬養部の設置記事がみられるが、現存する屯倉の地名と犬養という地名との近接例も多いことから、屯倉の守衛に番犬が用いられた（番犬を飼養していたのが犬養氏）だということが明らかになっており、屯倉や犬養部の設置時期も安閑天皇の頃（6世紀前半頃）に始まったと推察される。
sen.e: In an entry for August of the same year, there is an article pertaining to the establishment of inukaibe (corporations of dog keepers) but it is clear from the numerous examples in which surviving miyake place names are located next to inube place names that watchdogs were used to guard miyake (watchdogs were reared by the Inukai clan), and it is surmised that the establishment of miyake and inukaibe also began during the reign of Emperor Ankan (first half of the 6th century).

In an entry for August of the same year, there is an article pertaining to the establishment of inukaibe (corporations of dog keepers) but it is clear from the numerous examples in which surviving miyake place names are located next to inube place names that watchdogs were used to guard miyake (watchdogs were reared by the Inukai clan), and it is surmised that the establishment of miyake and inukaibe also began during the reign of Emperor Ankan (first half of the 6th century).

In an entry for September of the same year, there is an article pertaining to the establishment of inukaibe (corporations of dog keepers) but it is clear from the numerous examples in which surviving miyake place names are located next to inube place names that watchdogs were used to guard miyake (watchdogs were reared by the Inukai clan), and it is surmised that the establishment of miyake and inukaibe also began during the reign of Emperor Ankan (first half of the sixth century).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: この屯倉がある程度発達・広域展開した段階で、屯倉を拠点として、直接的に地方を把握・管轄した単位が県（コホリ）であり、のちに律令制における郡（コホリ）へと発展していったと考えられている。
sen.e: When these miyake developed and expanded to a certain size, they became kohori which were directly administered and controlled, and it is believed that they ater developed into the kohori of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

When these miyake developed and expanded to a certain size, they became kohori which were directly administered and controlled, and it is believed that they ater developed into the kohori of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

When these miyake developed and expanded to a certain size, they became the bases of kohori (written as 県 in Chinese characters), which was a unit that the central government directly administered and controlled in local areas, and it is believed that they later developed into the kohori (written as 郡) of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。一部翻訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 県（アガタ）と県（コホリ）との違いは、前者が在地首長の支配力に依存し、間接的に地方を把握するものであったのに対し、後者は直接的に地方の把握・支配の体系を作り出そうとしていたところにあるだろう。
sen.e: The difference between agata and kohori may be that the former depends on the control of a local head and managed indirectly, whereas the latter was part of an organization that attempted direct management and control.

The difference between agata and kohori may be that the former depends on the control of a local head and managed indirectly, whereas the latter was part of an organization that attempted direct management and control.

The difference between agata and kohori may be that the former depends on the control of a local head and managed indirectly, whereas the latter was part of an organization that attempted direct management and control.

tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: ヤマト政権は、地方の大首長を国造などに任命し、政治的支配をそのまま認める形で、全国的に支配していた。
sen.e: The Yamato Dynasty appointed local leaders as kuni no miyatsuko, and controlled all of the provinces via such political control.
The Yamato Dynasty appointed local leaders as kuni no miyatsuko, and controlled all of the provinces via such political control.
The Yamato Dynasty appointed local leaders as kuni no miyatsuko, and controlled all of the provinces via such political control.

sen.j: しかし、吉備国造や筑紫国造（527年の磐井の乱）などの反抗もあったが、古代国家統一の情勢にあり、日本の古代国家の成立期に当たると考えられている。
sen.e: However, despite the opposition of the kuni no miyatsuko of provinces including Kibi Province and Tsukushi Province, it is though from the fact that this reflects the unification of the nation that it was this period in which ancient Japan was established.

However, despite the opposition of the kuni no miyatsuko of provinces including Kibi Province and Tsukushi Province, it is though from the fact that this reflects the unification of the nation that it was this period in which ancient Japan was established.

However, despite the opposition of the kuni no miyatsuko of provinces including Kibi Province and Tsukushi Province (Iwai War in 527), it is thought from the fact that this reflects the unification of the nation that it was this period in which ancient Japan was established.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。翻訳を追加しました。

sen.j: これは、継体朝が終わり欽明朝が始まった時期に当たる。
sen.e: This was the period at the end of Emperor Keitai's reign and the beginning of Emperor Kimmei's reign.
This was the period at the end of Emperor Keitai's reign and the beginning of Emperor Kimmei's reign.
This was the period at the end of Emperor Keitai's reign and the beginning of Emperor Kinmei's reign.

tit.e: The Local Bureaucratic System under he Ritsuryo System
The Local Bureaucratic System under he Ritsuryo System
The local bureaucratic system under the ritsuryo system
tit.cmt: スペルを修正しました。小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 地方の行政組織が全国的規模で動き出したのは天武朝においてであったと推定されている。
sen.e: It is assumed that it was during the reign of Emperor Tenmu that the organization of local administration spread throughout the entire country.
It is assumed that it was during the reign of Emperor Tenmu that the organization of local administration spread throughout the entire country.
It is assumed that it was during the reign of Emperor Tenmu that the organization of local administration spread throughout the entire country.

sen.j: その基礎となる戸は、正丁（せいてい）成年男子を三丁ないし四丁含むような編成を編戸（へんこ）といい、一戸一兵士という、軍団の兵士を選ぶ基礎単位になった。
sen.e: The basic households of this system were called henko (the organization of the people) which included three or four seitei (men in good health between 21 and 60 years of age) and were the fundamental unit from which gundan (army corps) soldiers were selected in what was known as one soldier per household.

The basic households of this system were called henko (the organization of the people) which included three or four seitei (men in good health between 21 and 60 years of age) and were the fundamental unit from which gundan (army corps) soldiers were selected in what was known as one soldier per household.

The basic households of this system were called henko (the organization of the people) which included three or four seitei (men in good health between 21 and 60 years of age) and were the fundamental unit from which gundan (army corps) soldiers were selected in what was known as one soldier per household.

sen.j: 行政区画は、天皇の権力の及ぶ範囲、畿内（大和・摂津・河内（後、和泉が分立）・山城）と七道（東海・東山・北陸・山陰・山陽・南海・西海）に分け（道制）、その下に66国と壱岐国（いき）嶋、対馬国（つしま）嶋が置かれた。
sen.e: Administrative areas were divided between the areas ruled by the emperor, the Kinai (territories in the vicinity of the capital and under direct imperial rule) region (Yamato, Settsu, Kawachi (Izumi later became separate), and Yamashiro), and the shichido (the seven districts of ancient Japan - Tokaido, Tosando, Hokurikudo, Sanindo, Sanyodo, Nankaido and Saikaido) (circuit system), and 66 provinces were created below these in addition to Iki Province and Tsushima Province.

Administrative areas were divided between the areas ruled by the emperor, the Kinai (territories in the vicinity of the capital and under direct imperial rule) region (Yamato, Settsu, Kawachi (Izumi later became separate), and Yamashiro), and the shichido (the seven districts of ancient Japan - Tokaido, Tosando, Hokurikudo, Sanindo, Sanyodo, Nankaido and Saikaido) (circuit system), and 66 provinces were created below these in addition to Iki Province and Tsushima Province.

Administrative areas were divided between the areas ruled by the emperor, the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara - Yamato, Settsu, Kawachi [Izumi later became separate], and Yamashiro), and the shichido (the seven districts of ancient Japan - Tokaido, Tosando, Hokurikudo, Sanindo, Sanyodo, Nankaido and Saikaido) (called "Dosei," a system of administrative areas according to main roads), and 66 provinces were created below these in addition to Iki Province and Tsushima Province.
sen.cmt: 道制→"Dosei," a system of administrative areas according to main roads としました(定訳不明です）。

sen.j: このような行政区画以外にも、東国・坂東と陸奥国・出羽国があった。
sen.e: In addition to these administrative areas, there were also Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and Bando (old Kanto region) as well as Mutsu Province and Dewa Province.
In addition to these administrative areas, there were also Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and Bando (old Kanto region) as well as Mutsu Province and Dewa Province.
In addition to these administrative areas, there were also Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and Bando (old Kanto region) as well as Mutsu Province and Dewa Province.

sen.j: 行政組織は全て太政官左右弁官局の共同管轄下に置かれた。
sen.e: The administrative organization was all under the joint control of daijokan (Grand Council of State) Oversight Department of the Left and Right.
The administrative organization was all under the joint control of daijokan (Grand Council of State) Oversight Department of the Left and Right.
The administrative organization was all under the joint control of daijokan (Grand Council of State) Oversight Department of the Left and Right.

sen.j: 地方は一般に国・郡・里の行政組織に編成され、それぞれ国司・郡司・里長が置かれた。
sen.e: The administrative organization of areas generally consisted of provinces, districts and villages and these were headed by kokushi (provincial governors), gunji (district managers) and richo (village chiefs) respectively.

The administrative organization of areas generally consisted of provinces, districts and villages and these were headed by kokushi (provincial governors), gunji (district managers) and richo (village chiefs) respectively.

The administrative organization of areas generally consisted of provinces, districts and villages and these were headed by kokushi (provincial governors), gunji (district managers) and richo (village chiefs) respectively.

sen.j: 里は、715年（霊亀元）郷に改め、郷を2、3の里に分ける。
sen.e: In 715, villages were replaced by go (townships) which were composed of 2 or 3 ri/sato (neighbourhoods).
In 715, villages were replaced by go (townships) which were composed of 2 or 3 ri/sato (neighbourhoods).
In 715, villages were replaced by go (townships) which were composed of 2 or 3 ri/sato.
sen.cmt: 既出単語の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 国は大区画であり、群は中区画である。
sen.e: The kuni (province) was the largest administrative subdivision and the gun (district) was the mid-level administrative subdivision.
The kuni (province) was the largest administrative subdivision and the gun (district) was the mid-level administrative subdivision.
The kuni was the largest administrative subdivision and the gun was the mid-level administrative subdivision.
sen.cmt: 既出単語の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 群は大宝令（701年大宝元年）以前は評と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Before 701, gun were called kori/hyo.
Before 701, gun were called kori/hyo.
Before Taiho-ryo (Taiho Code) (in 701), gun were called kori/hyo.
sen.cmt: 大宝令 を追加しました。

sen.j: 地方の役所は官衙（かんが）といい、国と群に置かれ、国府（国衙）・群家（郡衙）といった。
sen.e: Local government offices were called nanga, located in provinces and districts and known as kokufu (or kokuga - provincial offices) and guke (or gunga - district offices).
Local government offices were called nanga, located in provinces and districts and known as kokufu (or kokuga - provincial offices) and guke (or gunga - district offices).
Local government offices were called kanga, located in provinces and districts and known as kokufu (or kokuga - provincial offices) and guke (or gunga - district offices).
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 地方の行政機関は、庶民を統制して、租税を収奪する機構である。
sen.e: Local administrative bodies were responsible for controlling the common people and collecting taxes.
Local administrative bodies were responsible for controlling the common people and collecting taxes.
Local administrative bodies were responsible for controlling the common people and collecting taxes.

sen.j: 中央政府と地方行政組織を結ぶ日本の古代道路（幅約6～12メートル）が整備され、さらに、関や駅なども整備された。
sen.e: The roads (6-12m wide) of ancient Japan which linked central government with regional administration organizations were built, and barriers and umaya (facilities for providing houses, food, etc.) were constructed.

The roads (6-12m wide) of ancient Japan which linked central government with regional administration organizations were built, and barriers and umaya (facilities for providing houses, food, etc.) were constructed.

The roads (6-12 meters wide) of ancient Japan which linked central government with regional administration organizations were built, and seki (barriers) and umaya (facilities for providing houses, food, etc.) were constructed.
sen.cmt: 関 を追加しました。

sen.j: 国司は、守（かみ）・介（すけ）・掾（じょう）・目（さかん）・史生（しせい）が置かれた。
sen.e: Kokushi consisted of kami, suke, jo, sakan and shisho.
Kokushi consisted of kami, suke, jo, sakan and shisho.
Kokushi consisted of kami, suke, jo, sakan and shisei.

sen.j: 国司は、中央から天皇のミコトモチ（御言持）として交替で赴任し、郡司を指揮して国内の支配に当たった。
sen.e: Kokushi were appointed from central government on an alternate basis as mikotomochi (a court official dispatched to a provincial post by imperial order) of the emperor, and were responsible for governing the province by serving as commanders of gunji (district managers).

Kokushi were appointed from central government on an alternate basis as mikotomochi (a court official dispatched to a provincial post by imperial order) of the emperor, and were responsible for governing the province by serving as commanders of gunji (district managers).

Kokushi were appointed from central government on an alternate basis as mikotomochi (a court official dispatched to a provincial post by imperial order) of the emperor, and were responsible for governing the province by serving as commanders of gunji (district managers).

sen.j: 国にも大・上・中・下の四等級があり、中国には介がなく、下国にはさらに掾も置かれないなど、職員の異同があるが、等級区分の基準はつまびらかではない。
sen.e: Provinces were ranked according to their size, as taikoku, jokoku, chukoku and gekoku, and were governed by different officials so that, for example, chugkoku would not have a suke and gekoku would not have a jo, but the size classification criteria are unknown.

Provinces were ranked according to their size, as taikoku, jokoku, chukoku and gekoku, and were governed by different officials so that, for example, chugkoku would not have a suke and gekoku would not have a jo, but the size classification criteria are unknown.

Provinces were ranked according to their size, as taikoku, jokoku, chukoku and gekoku, and were governed by different officials so that, for example, chukoku would not have a suke and gekoku would not have a jo, but the size classification criteria are unknown.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 国は、天武10年(681年)以前に、律令制の国が成立していたと考えられる。
sen.e: It is thought that the ritsuryo system provinces were established prior to the year 681.
It is thought that the ritsuryo system provinces were established prior to the year 681.
It is thought that the ritsuryo system provinces were established prior to the year 681.

sen.j: 伝飛鳥板蓋宮址から多数の木簡が出土し、それらの木簡の中に「辛巳年」という「天武十年」に相当する年紀が書かれていた。
sen.e: Numerous mokkan (narrow strips of wood on which an official message were written) have been excavated at Den Asuka Itabukimiya Ato (the supposed ruins of Asuka-Itabuki-no-miya Palace), and within these is written a"kanotomi year" which is equivalent to the 10th year of the reign of Emperor Tenmu (683).

Numerous mokkan (narrow strips of wood on which an official message were written) have been excavated at Den Asuka Itabukimiya Ato (the supposed ruins of Asuka-Itabuki-no-miya Palace), and within these is written a"kanotomi year" which is equivalent to the 10th year of the reign of Emperor Tenmu (683).

Numerous mokkan (narrow strips of wood on which an official message were written) have been excavated at Den Asuka Itabukimiya Ato (the supposed ruins of Asuka-Itabuki-no-miya Palace), and within these is written a 'kanotomi year' which is equivalent to the 10th year of the reign of Emperor Tenmu (681).
sen.cmt: 天武十年→681 としました。

tit.cmt: 既出のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 因みに、諸国には軍団が設置され、国司がこれを統率した。
sen.e: A gundan was stationed in each province and was commanded by the kokushi.
A gundan was stationed in each province and was commanded by the kokushi.
A gundan was stationed in each province and was commanded by the kokushi.

sen.j: 軍団は、兵士千人で構成され、大毅（だいき）一人・少毅二人がおかれた。
sen.e: Gundan were composed of 1,000 soldiers and included one daiki officer and two shoki officers.
Gundan were composed of 1,000 soldiers and included one daiki officer and two shoki officers.
Gundan were composed of 1,000 soldiers and included one daiki officer and two shoki officers.

sen.j: その内部は、五十人で一隊（騎兵隊・歩兵隊）で構成され、隊正（たいせい、五十長）が隊を、旅帥（りょそち、百長）が二隊（百人）を、校尉（こうい、二百長）が四隊をそれぞれ統率した。
sen.e: Within gundan, platoons (cavalry/infantry) were composed of 50 men, and each platoon was commanded by a taisei (commander of 50 men), two platoons (100 men) were commanded by a ryosochi (commander of 100 men) and four platoons (200 men) were commanded by a koi (commander of 200 men).

Within gundan, platoons (cavalry/infantry) were composed of 50 men, and each platoon was commanded by a taisei (commander of 50 men), two platoons (100 men) were commanded by a ryosochi (commander of 100 men) and four platoons (200 men) were commanded by a koi (commander of 200 men).

sen.j: そのほかに事務職員の主張が一人置かれた。
sen.e: In addition, one member of administrative staff was embedded.
In addition, one member of administrative staff was embedded.
In addition, one member of administrative staff was embedded.

sen.j: 実際は千人に満たない軍団もあった。
sen.e: In reality there were also gundan that had fewer than 1,000 men.
In reality there were also gundan that had fewer than 1,000 men.
In reality there were also gundan that had fewer than 1,000 men.

sen.j: 六百人以上の場合は、大・少毅各一人、五百人以下ならば、ただ毅が一人置かれた。
sen.e: In the case that gundan had more than 600 men, there was one daiki and one shoki, and if comprised of fewer than 500 men, there was only one such ki commander.
In the case that gundan had more than 600 men, there was one daiki and one shoki, and if comprised of fewer than 500 men, there was only one such ki commander.

sen.j: 大毅・少毅（あわせて軍毅という）もまた郡領と同じく在地の首長層から任命された。
sen.e: Like gunryo (collective term for the dairyo and shoryo ranks of district manager), daiki and shoki (collectively called gunki) were also appointed from local leaders.
Like gunryo (collective term for the dairyo and shoryo ranks of district manager), daiki and shoki (collectively called gunki) were also appointed from local leaders.
Like gunryo (collective term for the dairyo and shoryo ranks of district manager), daiki and shoki (collectively called gunki) were also appointed from local leaders.

sen.j: 郡司は、大領（だいりょう）・少領（しょうりょう）・主政（しゅせい）・主帳（しゅちょう）が置かれた。
sen.e: Gunji consisted of dairyo, shoryo, shusei and shucho.
Gunji consisted of dairyo, shoryo, shusei and shucho.
Gunji consisted of dairyo, shoryo, shusei and shucho.

sen.j: 大領・少領を合わせて郡領という。
sen.e: Dairyo and shoryo were collectively called gunryo.
Dairyo and shoryo were collectively called gunryo.
Dairyo and shoryo were collectively called gunryo.

sen.j: 郡領にはかつての国造一族などの在地首長が任ぜられた。
sen.e: Local heads such as family members of kuni no miyatsuko were appointed as gunryo.
Local heads such as family members of kuni no miyatsuko were appointed as gunryo.
Local heads such as family members of kuni no miyatsuko were appointed as gunryo.

sen.j: 終身の職であった。
sen.e: The position was held for life.
The position was held for life.
The position was held for life.

sen.j: 郡は二十里、二十里は千戸を上限として、その領内に含まれる里数によって五等級に区分される。
sen.e: Provinces were restricted to 20 villages in which 20 villages was comprised of 1,000 households, and were classified as one of five grades depending on the number of villages within the territory.
Provinces were restricted to 20 villages in which 20 villages was comprised of 1,000 households, and were classified as one of five grades depending on the number of villages within the territory.
Distircts were restricted to 20 villages in which 20 villages was comprised of 1,000 households, and were classified as one of five grades depending on the number of villages within the territory.

sen.j: 大郡は十六～二十里、上郡は十二～十五里、中郡は八～十一里、下郡は四～七里、小郡二～三里で、下郡には主政が置かれず、小郡では大領・少領を区別せずにただ領一人にを置いた。
sen.e: Daigun consisted of 16-20 villages, jogun of 12-15, chugun of 8-11, gegun of 4-7 and shogun of 2-3, among which gegun did not have a shusei, and shogun did not differentiate between dairyo and shoryo but rather there was only a single manager.

Daigun consisted of 16-20 villages, jogun of 12-15, chugun of 8-11, gegun of 4-7 and shogun of 2-3, among which gegun did not have a shusei, and shogun did not differentiate between dairyo and shoryo but rather there was only a single manager.

Daigun consisted of 16-20 villages, jogun of 12-15, chugun of 8-11, gegun of 4-7 and shogun of 2-3, among which gegun did not have a shusei, and shogun did not differentiate between dairyo and shoryo but rather there was only a single manager.

sen.j: 郡は、六世紀の中葉頃の欽明朝に屯倉の設置が拡大されていき、ヤマト政権の地方政治組織となっていった。
sen.e: Districts grew from the established miyake during the reign of Emperor Kimmei in the mid-6th century to become part of the local administration organization of the Yamato Dynasty.
Districts grew from the established miyake during the reign of Emperor Kimmei in the mid-6th century to become part of the local administration organization of the Yamato Dynasty.
Districts grew from the established miyake during the reign of Emperor Kinmei in the mid-sixth century to become part of the local administration organization of the Yamato Dynasty.

sen.j: 史の支配の及ぶ土地と人間の総体を指して「コオリ」と呼んだらしい。
sen.e: It appears to be the case that land and people under the control of a shi (clerk) was collectively called a "kori".
It appears to be the case that land and people under the control of a shi (clerk) was collectively called a "kori".
It appears to be the case that land and people under the control of a shi (clerk) was collectively called a 'kori.'

sen.j: コオリの称は、律令制下の郡の和訓とされ、現代まで受け継がれている。
sen.e: The name "kori" was the Japanese reading for the gun (district) character and continues to be used today.
The name "kori" was the Japanese reading for the gun (district) character and continues to be used today.
The name "kori" was the Japanese reading for gun (郡) and continues to be used today.

sen.j: 郡の制度は701年（大宝元）施行の大宝令に始まるが、それ以前の地方行政組織は「評」と書かれ、「コオリ」と称された。
sen.e: The district system began with the enacting of the Taiho Code in 701 but regional administration organization before this time also consisted of "kori" which was written using a different character.
The district system began with the enacting of the Taiho Code in 701 but regional administration organization before this time also consisted of "kori" which was written using a different character.

The district system began with the enacting of the Taiho Code in 701 but regional administration organization before this time also consisted of 'kori' which was written using a different character (評).

sen.j: 里は五十戸で構成された。
sen.e: A ri/sato (village) consisted of 50 households.
A ri/sato (village) consisted of 50 households.
A ri/sato consisted of 50 households.
sen.cmt: 既出単語の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: その統率者が里長で末端行政を担った。
sen.e: Villages were headed by a richo who was responsible for low level administration.
Villages were headed by a richo who was responsible for low level administration.
Villages were headed by a richo who was responsible for low level administration.

sen.j: 715年（霊亀元）に里は郷（ごう）と改称され、郷は2～3里に分かれ統率者は郷長であった。
sen.e: In 715, villages were replaced by go (townships) which were composed of 2 or 3 ri/sato (neighbourhoods) and headed by a gocho (township chief).
In 715, villages were replaced by go (townships) which were composed of 2 or 3 ri/sato (neighbourhoods) and headed by a gocho (township chief).
In 715, villages were renamed by go which were composed of 2 or 3 ri/sato and headed by a gocho (township chief).
sen.cmt: 既出単語の補足を削除しました。Renamed としました。

sen.j: 郷里制に変わった。
sen.e: This was the shift to the township-neighbourhood system.
This was the shift to the township-neighbourhood system.
This was the shift to the gorisei (township-neighborhood system).
sen.cmt: 郷里制 追加しました。

sen.j: 里には里正が置かれたが、740年（天平12）頃を境に里は廃止され郷制に移行した。
sen.e: Each village had a local governor but villages were abolished circa 740 and replaced by the township system.
Each village had a local governor but villages were abolished circa 740 and replaced by the township system.
Each village had a head of village called "risei" but villages were abolished circa 740 and replaced by the gosei (township system).
sen.cmt: 郷制 追加しました。

sen.j: 全国はさらに畿内・七道に区分される。
sen.e: Above the level of provinces, the entire country was divided into the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and the shichido (the seven districts of ancient Japan).
Above the level of provinces, the entire country was divided into the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and the shichido (the seven districts of ancient Japan).
Above the level of provinces, the entire country was divided into the Kinai region and the shichido.
sen.cmt: 既出単語の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 畿内は当初大和国（やまと）・河内国（かわち）・摂津国（せっつ）・山城国（やましろ）の四カ国からなり、四畿内と称されたが、のち河内の国から和泉国（いずみ）の国が分立して五畿内となった。
sen.e: The Kinai region consisted of Yamato Province, Kawachi Province, Settsu Province and Yamashiro Province, which were called "Shikinai" (lit. Four Kinai Provinces) but Izumi Province later became independent from Kawachi province and the region became known as "Gokinai" (lit. Five Kinai Provinces).

The Kinai region consisted of Yamato Province, Kawachi Province, Settsu Province and Yamashiro Province, which were called "Shikinai" (lit. Four Kinai Provinces) but Izumi Province later became independent from Kawachi province and the region became known as "Gokinai" (lit. Five Kinai Provinces).

The Kinai region consisted of Yamato Province, Kawachi Province, Settsu Province and Yamashiro Province, which were called "Shikinai" (lit. Four Kinai Provinces) but Izumi Province later became independent from Kawachi province and the region became known as "Gokinai" (lit. Five Kinai Provinces).

tit.cmt: dosei としました（既出のため）。

sen.j: 七道は京を中心にして四方にのびる幹線交通路（水路も含む）に沿った行政区分で、東海道・東山道・北陸道・山陰道・山陽道・南海道・西海道である。
sen.e: The shichido were administrative areas that followed the main roads which stretched away from the capital in all directions, and consisted of Tokaido, Tosando, Hokurikudo, Sanindo, Sanyodo, Nankaido and Saikaido.

The shichido were administrative areas that followed the main roads which stretched away from the capital in all directions, and consisted of Tokaido, Tosando, Hokurikudo, Sanindo, Sanyodo, Nankaido and Saikaido.

The shichido were administrative areas that followed the main roads (including water channels) which stretched away from the capital in all directions, and consisted of Tokaido, Tosando, Hokurikudo, Sanindo, Sanyodo, Nankaido and Saikaido.
sen.cmt: 水路 を追加しました。

sen.j: このうち西海道には大宰府（だざいふ）が筑前の国に置かれ、国境の防衛や外交事務に当たるとともに、管内諸国島を国、郡、里の三段階で統轄した。
sen.e: Among these, Saikai do contained Dazai-fu (the local government office in Kyushu region) which was located in Chikuzen Province and, in addition to protecting national borders and conducting external affairs, served to govern all islands under its jurisdiction according to the province-district-village system.

Among these, Saikai do contained Dazai-fu (the local government office in Kyushu region) which was located in Chikuzen Province and, in addition to protecting national borders and conducting external affairs, served to govern all islands under its jurisdiction according to the province-district-village system.

Among these, Saikaido contained Dazai-fu (the local government office in Kyushu region) which was located in Chikuzen Province and, in addition to protecting national borders and conducting external affairs, served to govern all islands under its jurisdiction according to the koku-gun-ri system (province-district-village system).
sen.cmt: 国郡里 を追加しました。

sen.j: 東北には多賀城（宮城県多賀城市）を置いて、周辺諸国を統率する広域行政を敷いた。
sen.e: Taga-jo Castle (Tagajo City, Miyagi Prefecture) in the northeast established a wide area of control which included the surrounding provinces.
Taga-jo Castle (Tagajo City, Miyagi Prefecture) in the northeast established a wide area of control which included the surrounding provinces.
Taga-jo Castle (Tagajo City, Miyagi Prefecture) in the northeast established a wide area of control which included the surrounding provinces.

tit.e: Settsu Shiki (Administrative Agency of Settsu Province)
Settsu Shiki (Administrative Agency of Settsu Province)
Settsu Shiki (Administrative Agency of Settsu Province)

sen.j: さらに摂津の国には摂津職（せっつしき）が置かれ、国司の職務も兼ねた。
sen.e: Settsu Shiki was located in Settsu Province and conducted the duties of a kokushi.
Settsu Shiki was located in Settsu Province and conducted the duties of a kokushi.
Settsu Shiki was located in Settsu Province and conducted the duties of a kokushi.

sen.j: 摂津職は、京に置かれ難波津を管理し、京と西国の間を上下する公使の検査などを本来の任務としたが、天武朝に難波が陪都（副都）とされ、また聖武朝にも難波宮が造営されると、その管理にも当たった。
sen.e: Settsu Shiki was situated in the captial and originally served to manage Naniwa no Tsu (Naniwa Port) as well as conduct inspections of envoys travelling between the capital and the west of the country, but later went on to conduct the administration of Naniwa which was made a baito (secondary capital city) during the Reign of Emperor Tenmu and Naniwanomiya Palace which was constructed during the reign of Emperor Shomu

sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 難波宮の廃止に伴い793年（延暦12）には摂津職が廃止され、摂津国と改めた。
sen.e: Settsu Shiki was abolished in 793 with the abolition of Naniwanomiya Palace and was replaced by Settsu Province.
Settsu Shiki was abolished in 793 with the abolition of Naniwanomiya Palace and was replaced by Settsu Province.
Settsu Shiki was abolished in 793 with the abolition of Naniwanomiya Palace and was replaced by Settsu Province.

sen.j: 京（平城京・平安京ほか）には左右の京職（きょうしき）が置かれ、京内の政務全般をつかさどった。
sen.e: The affairs of the capital city (Heijo-kyo, Heian-kyo etc.) were governed by Kyoshiki.
The affairs of the capital city (Heijo-kyo, Heian-kyo etc.) were governed by Kyoshiki.
The affairs of the capital city (Heijo-kyo, Heian-kyo etc.) were governed by Kyoshiki.

sen.j: 京は御所からみて東側が左京、西側が右京である。
sen.e: From the view of the imperial palace, the sakyo (left of the capital) was on the eastern side and the ukyo (right of the capital) was on the western side.
From the view of the imperial palace, the sakyo (left of the capital) was on the eastern side and the ukyo (right of the capital) was on the western side.
From the view of the imperial palace, the sakyo (left of the capital) was on the eastern side and the ukyo (right of the capital) was on the western side.

sen.j: 縦横の大路によって碁盤目のようにきれいに区画された。
sen.e: Vertical and horizontal main streets neatly divided the capital into sections like a grid.
Vertical and horizontal main streets neatly divided the capital into sections like a grid.
Vertical and horizontal main streets neatly divided the capital into sections like a grid.

sen.j: その区画を南北に連ねた列を坊（ぼう）と呼び、東西に並んだ区画を条（じょう）と呼んだ。
sen.e: Each column of these sections running from north to south was called a "bo" and each row running from east to west was called a "jo".
Each column of these sections running from north to south was called a "bo" and each row running from east to west was called a "jo".
Each column of these sections running from north to south was called a "bo" and each row running from east to west was called a "jo."
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を移動しました。

sen.j: 各坊には坊長が置かれ、左右京には条ごとに坊令（ぼうれい、条令）が置かれた。
sen.e: Each bo had a "bocho" (bo chief), and each jo in the left and right of the capital had a "borei" (jorei - jo chief).
Each bo had a "bocho" (bo chief), and each jo in the left and right of the capital had a "borei" (jorei - jo chief).
Each bo had a "bocho" (bo chief), and each jo in the left and right of the capital had a "borei" (jorei - jo chief).

sen.j: この京（京職）、条（坊令）、坊（坊長）の行政組織は、国（国司）、郡（郡司）、里（里長）と対応している。
sen.e: This capital city (kyochiki), jo (jorei) and bo (cho) administrative organization system corresponded to the province (provincial governor), district (district manager) and village (village chief) system.

This capital city (kyochiki), jo (jorei) and bo (cho) administrative organization system corresponded to the province (provincial governor), district (district manager) and village (village chief) system.
This capital city (kyoshiki), jo (jorei) and bo (bocho) administrative organization system corresponded to the koku (provincial governor), gun (district manager) and ri (village chief) system.
sen.cmt: 国・郡・里 を追加しました。

tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 和泉監と芳野監は716年頃特別行政区画・行政組織としてそれぞれ河内・大和から独立した。
sen.e: Izumi Gen and Yoshino Gen were special administrative areas/administrative organization systems that became independent from Kawachi Province and Yamato Province respectively.
Izumi Gen and Yoshino Gen were special administrative areas/administrative organization systems that became independent from Kawachi Province and Yamato Province respectively.
Izumi Gen and Yoshino Gen were special administrative areas/administrative organization systems that became independent from Kawachi Province and Yamato Province respectively around 716.

sen.j: 和泉には茅渟宮が芳野には吉野宮が置かれていたためである。
sen.e: This was due to the presence of Chinu-no-Miya Palace in Izumi Gen and Yoshino Miya Palace in Yoshino Gen.
This was due to the presence of Chinu-no-Miya Palace in Izumi Gen and Yoshino Miya Palace in Yoshino Gen.
This was due to the presence of Chinu-no-Miya Palace in Izumi and Yoshino Miya Palace in Yoshino.

sen.j: 後に廃止されたが和泉はその後国として独立した。
sen.e: These were later abolished but Izumi Gen later became an independent province.
These were later abolished but Izumi Gen later became an independent province.
These were later abolished but Izumi Gen later became an independent province.

sen.j: 河内職は道鏡が権力を握っていた時代､河内国に由義宮を建設し副都とした。
sen.e: Kawachi Shiki was a separate capital established during the period in which Dokyo held power when he constructed Yuge-no-Miya Palace in Kawachi Province.
Kawachi Shiki was a separate capital established during the period in which Dokyo held power when he constructed Yuge-no-Miya Palace in Kawachi Province.
Kawachi Shiki established Yuge-no-Miya Palace in Kawachi Province as a separate capital during the period in which Dokyo held power.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を一部変更しました。

sen.j: それに伴って河内国司を格上げして河内職とした。
sen.e: On completion, the office of Kawachi kokushi replaced by the special administration structure of Kawachi Shiki.
On completion, the office of Kawachi kokushi replaced by the special administration structure of Kawachi Shiki.
On completion, the office of Kawachi kokushi replaced by the special administration structure of Kawachi Shiki.

sen.j: 道鏡失脚によって元に戻った。
sen.e: The prior system was restored following the downfall of Dokyo.
The prior system was restored following the downfall of Dokyo.
The prior system was restored following the downfall of Dokyo.

sen.j: 鋳銭使はもともと貨幣鋳造のための機関であったが818年に長門国司を廃止して長門国の行政も担った。
sen.e: Jusenshi was originally an agancy that oversaw the minting of coins but in theyear 818 abolished the office of Nagato kokushi and took over the administration of Nagato Province.
Jusenshi was originally an agancy that oversaw the minting of coins but in theyear 818 abolished the office of Nagato kokushi and took over the administration of Nagato Province.

sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 825年に廃止されて長門国司は復活し貨幣鋳造は鋳銭司に引き継がれた。
sen.e: This was abolished in 825, the Nagato kokushi was restored and the juenshi took over the minting of coins.
This was abolished in 825, the Nagato kokushi was restored and the juenshi took over the minting of coins.
This was abolished in 825, the Nagato kokushi was restored and the jusenshi took over the minting of coins.

tit.j: 社会情勢の変化による官制
tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 天災による飢饉や疫病などが各地に広がり、盗賊や海賊が出没し、社会不安が広がった。
sen.e: The prevalent robbery and piracy that emerged as famine and disease caused by natural disasters spread throughout the country caused increased social unrest.
The prevalent robbery and piracy that emerged as famine and disease caused by natural disasters spread throughout the country caused increased social unrest.
The prevalent robbery and piracy that emerged as famine and disease caused by natural disasters spread throughout the country caused increased social unrest.

sen.j: 社会の動揺を軍事的な手段で鎮圧する武力的な措置をとった。
sen.e: The authorities suppressed social disturbances using military force.
The authorities suppressed social disturbances using military force.
The authorities suppressed social disturbances using military force.

sen.j: 731年（天平3）畿内に惣官（そうかん）、山陰・山陽・南海道に鎮撫使（ちんぶし）を新設。
sen.e: In 731, the position of sokan (a military position with power over the provinces of the Kinai region) was created in the Kinai region, and the position of chinbushi (an official charged with pacifying public unrest) was established in Sanindo, Sanyodo and Nankaido.

In 731, the position of sokan (a military position with power over the provinces of the Kinai region) was created in the Kinai region, and the position of chinbushi (an official charged with pacifying public unrest) was established in Sanindo, Sanyodo and Nankaido.

In 731, the position of sokan (a military position with power over the provinces of the Kinai region) was created in the Kinai region, and the position of chinbushi (an official charged with pacifying public unrest) was established in Sanindo, Sanyodo and Nankaido.

sen.j: 732年（天平4）東海・東山・山陰・西海道に節度使（せつどし）を任命。
sen.e: In 732, setsudoshi (military governors) were appointed in Tokaido, Tosando, Sanindo and Saikaido.
In 732, setsudoshi (military governors) were appointed in Tokaido, Tosando, Sanindo and Saikaido.
In 732, setsudoshi (military governors) were appointed in Tokaido, Tosando, Sanindo and Saikaido.

tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 737年（天平9）陸奥（むつ）と出羽（でわ）とを結ぶ道が開かれた。
sen.e: A road connecting Mutsu and Dewa was opened in the year 737.
A road connecting Mutsu and Dewa was opened in the year 737.
A road connecting Mutsu and Dewa was opened in the year 737.

sen.j: 東北に対する施策。
sen.e: This was a measure taken in the northeast of the country.
This was a measure taken in the northeast of the country.
This was a measure taken in the northeast of the country.

tit.j: 戸籍制度・地方行政組織関連の年表
tit.e: Chronology of the Family Registration System and Local Administration
Chronology of the Family Registration System and Local Administration
Chronology of the family registration system and local administration
tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 689年（持統4）飛鳥浄御原令、諸司に令一部二十二巻をわかつ。
sen.e: 689: Asuka Kiyomihara Code compiled and the 22 volumes distributed to all officials.
689: Asuka Kiyomihara Code compiled and the 22 volumes distributed to all officials.
689: Asuka Kiyomihara Code compiled and the 22 volumes distributed to all officials.

sen.j: 670年（天智9）全国的に戸籍（庚午年籍）を造る。
sen.e: 670: Nationwide family register (Kogo no Nenjaku) created.
670: Nationwide family register (Kogo no Nenjaku) created.
670: Nationwide family register (Kogo no Nenjaku) created.

sen.j: 690年（持統4）戸令により戸籍（庚寅年籍）を造る。
sen.e: 690: Family register (Koin no Nenjaku) created under the Code of Households.
690: Family register (Koin no Nenjaku) created under the Code of Households.
690: Family register (Koin no Nenjaku) created under the Code of Households.

sen.j: 702年（大宝2）大宝律令を諸国に領下する。
sen.e: 702: Taiho Code applied to all provinces.
702: Taiho Code applied to all provinces.
702: Taiho Code applied to all provinces.

sen.j: 703年（大宝3）庚午年籍を戸籍の原簿とする。
sen.e: 703: Kogo no Nenjaku becomes the original family register record.
703: Kogo no Nenjaku becomes the original family register record.
703: Kogo no Nenjaku becomes the original family register record.

sen.j: 715年（霊亀元）里を郷に改め、郷を2・3の里に分ける。
sen.e: 715: Ri/sato (villages) replaced by go (townships) which contain 2 or 3 ri/sato (neighborhoods).
715: Ri/sato (villages) replaced by go (townships) which contain 2 or 3 ri/sato (neighborhoods).
715: Ri/sato replaced by go which contain 2 or 3 ri/sato.
sen.cmt: 既出単語の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 718年（養老2）養老律令を選定する。
sen.e: 718: Yoro Code selected.
718: Yoro Code selected.
718: Yoro Code selected.

sen.j: 723年（養老7）墾田開発のため、三世一身法（さんぜいっしんのほう）を施行する。
sen.e: 723: Sanze-isshin Law (a law allowing farmers who cleared new lands to own them for a period of three generations) enacted for the agricultural development of reclaimed land.
723: Sanze-isshin Law (a law allowing farmers who cleared new lands to own them for a period of three generations) enacted for the agricultural development of reclaimed land.
723: Sanze-isshin Law (a law allowing farmers who cleared new lands to own them for a period of three generations) enacted for the agricultural development of reclaimed land.

sen.j: 11月奴卑口分田の班給を12歳以上とする。
sen.e: In November, the minimum age for the allotment of a rice-field for nuhi servant was set to 12 years.
In November, the minimum age for the allotment of a rice-field for nuhi servant was set to 12 years.
In December, the minimum age for the allotment of a rice-field for nuhi servant was set to 12 years.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。
